[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures may impede immediate clarity.
[LEXICON]: Some archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "saeculum mirabile", "epigoni") might require additional context for all readers.

[STRUCTURE]: Transitions between historical periods and ideas could be more explicitly signposted.
[CLARITY]: Assumptions about the reader's prior knowledge of historical events (e.g., the impact of the French Revolution on England) might leave some readers disconnected.

[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structures may impede smooth reading in some instances.
[LEXICON]: Occasional use of less common vocabulary (e.g., "lurid pictures", "despotic", "inarticulate") might slow some readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing intellectual life to the condition of the working class without a clear connector.
[STRUCTURE]: Non-linear progression of ideas (e.g., moving from 1812 to 1831, then to general statements, and back to specific historical events).
